"Are research papers a waste of time?" Absolutely not! The internet may give students and scholars easy access to sources, but many of these sources are flawed or unreliable in some way. Now more than ever, students need to know how to sift through information to find reliable sources and well-constructed arguments. Writing a research paper is still the best way to do this. Select a paper topic that you find interesting or important. Read and evaluate 10-15 reputable sources related to your topic, and then build an argument that engages with and contributes to this existing research. This might not be the most exciting assignment in the world (depends on the topic, I suppose) but it teaches skills that every college graduate should have. Growing up, I was always a high academic achiever. Still, I always asked my parents to proofread my work before turning it in. Those evenings in which my parents edited at my side turned out to improve my writing so much more than my teachers ever could. That one-on-one, painstakingly specific instruction taught me that active voice is preferable to passive and that there is a difference between formal, academic essays and casual, creative writing. Just because my parents helped me craft an essay didn't mean I didn't learn to become a better writer from that experience, and it certainly didn't make me dependent on them throughout my life. My younger sister, on the other hand, resisted their help, preferring to do her work alone. She became an exceptional writer and went to a great school. In the end, each kid has different needs. I don't think you can make a blanket statement saying "all parents should do this" or "all homework help (or homework, for that matter) is counterproductive."

"I -... - would not support the idea if I doubted our ability to put environmental safeguards in place." Putting "environmental safeguards" in place and preventing disasters are not the same thing. Standard, well intentioned engineering practice in oil production, refining, and transport includes safeguards like double and triple redundant fail safe systems. Still, engineered systems fail and all too recently we've had well-head blowouts (Deep Water Horizon), refinery explosions and fires, and oil transport disasters ranging from pipeline ruptures to tank train derailments to the Exxon Valdez. Imagine a perfect storm situation off Virginia Beach where a well head blowout coincided with a Hurricane Sandy. Crude oil from the Chesapeake to Iceland and a potentially mortal blow to already fragile shore communities and fisheries along the way. The only way to be 100% sure that the East Coast won't suffer catastrophic damage from oil production is to outlaw the outlandishly risky exploitation of hydrocarbons in our salty ocean waters.

I have two serious issues with plug-in cars, local and national. Locally, NH has the highest electric rates in the country (thanks, Seabrook). Nationally, plugging in is a huge waste of energy. To get a gallon of gas worth of electricity out of a wall socket, we need to put at least three gallons into the generator. Every time energy changes state, there is a loss: fuel to heat, heat to steam, steam to mechanical energy, mechanical to electrical, and in the car, electrical to battery, battery to mechanical, mechanical to tires, tires to motion. Add that to transmission losses, and you end up with a lot of waste instead of savings. Plug-in cars will add to the problem, not solve it.

I don't think you can make a blanket statement saying "all parents should do this" or "all homework help (or homework, for that matter) is counterproductive."
